Geography: Mid-Atlantic, New York, New York, United States
Dimensions: Candlestick (without bobeche) H. 11 1/4 in. (28.6 cm); 22 oz. 18 dwt. (712.9 g)
Credit Line: Gift of Mrs. Clermont L. Barnwell, 1964
Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History: American Silver Vessels for Wine, Beer, and Punch
Coffee, Tea, and Chocolate in Early Colonial America
Architecture, Furniture, and Silver from Colonial Dutch America
Description: These richly ornamented candlesticks and the accompanying snuffer stand were originally owned by Johannes Schuyler, the mayor of Albany from 1703 to 1706, and his wife, Elsie Staats Schuyler, who were married in 1695. The chinoiserie chasing on the bases is extremely rare in American silver.
Provenance: Elizabeth Staats Wendell (1659–1737) and Johannes Schuyler (1668–1747)
according to family history, by descent to Elizabeth Marié Barnwell (1860–1940)
to her daughter-in-law, Elizabeth Steward Morris Burrill (Mrs. Clermont Livingston) Barnwell (1895–1985)
gift to The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1964.
